description:
Dreissena polymorpha, commonly known as the zebra mussel, is a small freshwater bivalve mollusk that belongs to the family Dreissenidae. This species is native to the Ponto-Caspian region, which includes the Black Sea and Caspian Sea basins, but has become an invasive species in many parts of the world, including North America and Europe.

Zebra mussels have a distinctive striped shell pattern, which can range in color from dark brown to black, with alternating light and dark bands. They are typically small, with a maximum size of around 4 centimeters (1.6 inches) in length. These mussels are known for their ability to attach to various surfaces, such as rocks, docks, pipes, and even the shells of other mollusks, using byssal threads.

Zebra mussels are filter feeders, meaning they obtain their food by filtering suspended particles, including algae, bacteria, and organic matter, from the water column. This feeding behavior can have significant ecological impacts, as they can dramatically reduce the availability of plankton and other primary producers, thereby altering the entire food web in the invaded ecosystems.

Due to their rapid reproduction and ability to colonize new habitats, zebra mussels have become a major economic and environmental concern in many regions where they have been introduced. They can clog water intake pipes, reduce the efficiency of power plants and other industrial facilities, and disrupt native aquatic communities by outcompeting and displacing indigenous species.

Ongoing research and management efforts aim to understand the biology and ecology of Dreissena polymorpha, as well as to develop effective strategies for controlling and mitigating the impacts of this invasive species.
